Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Feast or Flee: How do Microzooplankton Detect and Avoid Predators?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals sense a multitude of tactile, olfactory, visual, and aural sensory cues from predators and prey, integrate these cues, and respond with appropriate behaviors; avoidance or prey capture, respectively. Understanding how animals integrate these multiple signals to evoke complex behaviors is one of the central challenges in the biology of behavior. Single celled eukaryotes have many of the same sensory characteristics, at the cellular level, as multicellular animals and therefore provide excellent conceptual and functional analogues of sensory and behavioral traits in higher organisms. The researcher will use a marine microzooplankton ciliate, Favella sp., as a model organism to investigate sensory mechanisms that allow them to perceive and integrate cues from predators and prey in order to successfully capture prey while avoiding predation. Because these single celled organisms represent an early evolving group of eukaryotes, characterization of their sensory capabilities will provide insights into the evolution of integrated cell signaling and emergent behavioral traits in multicellular organisms. Moreover, understanding the predator-prey interactions of these microzooplankton, a group of organisms responsible for consuming ~60 % of marine primary productivity, will enable a better understanding of the role they play in supporting marine food webs and in fluxes of nutrients in surface oceans. Both of these larger ecosystem scale processes have implications for marine ecosystem services (e.g. fisheries) and for biogeochemical cycles that impact our climate. In addition to these important science questions, the proposed research will foster cross-disciplinary collaboration of the graduate student with experts in microzooplankton ecology. Professional training, science communication and career development of the researcher will be promoted with support to attend high profile scientific meetings. The award will also allow the researcher to further develop and implement teaching programs for high school students that will help attract them to science and technology subjects at college level, and motivate them to become involved in research as undergraduates.

Microzooplankton alveolates (ciliates and dinoflagellates) transfer substantial amounts of energy from primary production to larger metazoan consumers. Underlying these predator-prey interactions are complex behaviors that allow them to efficiently capture preferred prey and evade predation by sensing and integrating a variety of stimuli from each. Despite the ecological importance of these behavioral interactions, no previous research has examined how microzooplankton are able to differentiate between predators and prey despite receiving similar types of sensory information from both. This proposal builds upon dissertation research investigating the sensory mechanisms that marine microzooplankton possess to sense and respond to signals from their prey. The first objective is to determine the behavioral responses of Favella sp. to dinoflagellate and copepod predators, and the effectiveness of these behavioral responses. High-speed videomicroscopy (250 fps) and particle tracking techniques will quantify the behavioral responses of Favella sp. to chemical, mechanical (contact) and hydrodynamic stimuli from predators and prey. The second objective will determine the mechanistic basis of behavioral responses to predators identified in objective 1. This will be accomplished using a combination of high-speed video microscopy, electrophysiology, and fluorescent ion-sensitive dyes to determine how ionotropic and metabotropic mechanisms mediate signal transduction and predator evasion behaviors. Particle image velocimetry will also be utilized to determine how the flow field surrounding Favella sp. may be modified during predator evasion behaviors to decrease its hydrodynamic signature and therefore the likelihood that it will be ingested. In summary, the proposed experiments will extend current research on ciliate-prey behavioral interactions to address the question of how this single celled organism can integrate microscale environmental cues to detect and consume appropriate prey, and evade ingestion by predators.

Intellectual Merit:

The recipient Michael Echevarria successfully completed his dissertation “Connecting alveolate sensory biology with trophic ecology in the marine plankton using the ciliate Favella sp. as a model” with support from the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant and is currently pursuing a postdoctoral research position at Purdue University. As a cell biologist and ecologist, Echevarria is interested in understanding the how single celled organisms can sense and respond to environmental stimuli with complex and sophisticated behaviors despite their relative simplicity. Because these organisms are the ancestors of more complex multicellular life, researching them gives insight into the sensory mechanisms in more complex organisms. The doctoral dissertation grant allowed for Echevarria to expand the scope of his research to investigate interactions of the unicellular Favella sp. with metazoan predators.

Echevarria examined behavioral interactions of Favella sp. with three predators: a larval fish and two types of copepods. He found that Favella sp. respond to both water motion generated and direct contact from predators with two distinct predator evasion behaviors; intermittent backward swimming and contraction into the lorica (the tough shell that surrounds Favella sp.). The award enabled Echevarria to purchase equipment, supplies and copepod cultures that were essential for this work. During the course of the grant he developed several high resolution imaging approaches that enabled the fast (ms) responses and microscale fluid flow around the ciliate cell to be visualized. Echevarria found that behavioral responses of Favella sp. were dependent on the type, intensity, and location of stimuli from predators, with more intense stimuli causing contraction and less intense stimuli causing backward swimming, and that behaviors were regulated by the electrical activity of the cell. Marine microzooplankton are important components of the marine food web representing a critical link between phytoplankton, zooplankton, and larval fish. This research has provided critical insight into the ecological success of marine microzooplankton by showing that they possess complex and sophisticated sensory mechanisms that allow them to sense the presence of predators and prey and respond with appropriate prey capture or predator evasion behaviors. In addition the research provided evidence that Favella sp. possess similar sensory mechanisms to higher organisms, including fast ‘animal like’ action potentials, indicating that these mechanisms independently evolved multiple times over the course of evolutionary history. This work has resulted in a 3 manuscripts (one published in a peer reviewed scientific journal and 2 under submission). In addition, this work was disseminated at a variety of meetings including the American Society of Limnology and Oceanography Annual Meetings and presented at the prestigious International Microscale Ocean Biophysics Meeting at the Aspen Center for Physics where Echevarria was awarded best student talk.

Broader Impacts

The doctoral dissertation improvement grant allowed Echevarria to train and mentor 6 undergraduates and one master’s student in research techniques ranging from reagent preparation and cell culture to advanced microscopy and electrophysiology techniques. Echevarria mentored 2 of these undergraduates over the course of multi-year independent research projects, with one going on to pursue a joint Ph.D. in Biological and Environmental Sciences at the University of Rhode Island. Her research was presented at multiple conferences, resulted in an Honor’s undergraduate thesis, and is currently being submitted for publication in a peer reviewed scientific journal. The work developed by Echevarria also provided knowledge and resources that were instrumental in establishing a multi-investigator NOAA-funded project on marine microplastics at UNC-Wilmington.

The doctoral dissertation grant allowed for Echevarria to perform multiple public outreach events annually that instructed the public on the importance of marine microorganisms in the marine food web and the techniques marine biologists use to study these organisms. Echevarria partnered with MarineQuest, the academic enrichment program at UNCW, to design a series of exercises that high school seniors conducted over the course of three summers. During the exercises students investigated different aspects of how a marine microorganism, the rotifer Brachionus rotundiformis, feeds. They used scanning electron microscopy to examine rotifer mouthparts, confocal fluorescence microscopy to examine rotifer feeding in action, and spectrophotometry to measure rotifer feeding rates. These experiences were assessed using student and teacher surveys, with very positive results. Overall the project impacted over 50 pre-college teens and 100 members of the public in outreach activities.
